description: From Middle English behoven, bihoven (“to be necessary, requisite; to be compelled or required (to do something)”), from Old English behōfian (“to need; to be necessary”), from Proto-Germanic *bihōfōną (“advantage, behoof, profit; need”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *keh₂p- (“to grab, seize”). The word is cognate with Old Frisian bihōvia (“to need”), Dutch behoeven (“to need”), obsolete German behufen (cf. Behuf), Danish behøve (“to need”),  Norwegian behøve (“to need”), Swedish behöva (“to have use for, to need”).

verbs.description: behove (third-person singular simple present behoves, present participle behoving, simple past and past participle behoved)

entries.meaning: (transitive, formal) To be in the best interest of; to benefit.
(intransitive, formal) To be needful, meet or becoming.
